intro: Lippia macrophylla, commonly known as Mexican mint or winter mint, is a flowering plant native to Central America and parts of the southern United States. It is a perennial herb that typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, featuring opposite, lance-shaped leaves with a strong, minty aroma. The plant produces small, white or pale purple flowers in clusters, which bloom from late spring to early autumn. It thrives in well-drained soil and full sun, making it a popular choice for ornamental and culinary use. Its aromatic properties make it a valuable plant in both traditional medicine and modern herbal applications.
